subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Quiki-pedia?
msgSnippet: 1)Sorry, I thought we were talking about extra code points for senior QS again - an idea which I m strongly allergic to. :) 2)I m not sure I ve understood you,
messageBody:
1)Sorry, I thought we were talking about extra code points for senior QS
again - an idea which I'm strongly allergic to. :)

2)I'm not sure I've understood you, could you explain?
The way I see it I don't think there is too big an issue with having a
mishmash of dialects on a page.
An end user would still be able to read the article.
And it would be possible to put in redirects for the common spellings of
an article's title.
I think it's more about having a consistent style and making searching
easier.

Of course you could have a Quikipedia for each dialect i.e.:
quik_us.wikipedia.org
quik_gb.wikipedia.org

Or we could go with giving creating a duplicate of each article in each
dialect, i.e.:
quik.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quikscript_(us)
quik.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quikscript_(gb)

Or we could just copy the text and paste it for each dialect one after
another.

All of those options involve a lot of needless duplication of work and
disk space unfortunately.

tim_rice09 wrote:
>
> Some small questions and suggestions:
> 1: The abbreviations of Senior Quickscript iron out most dialectal
> differences, and work pretty well with only the basic forty four
> letters. Why not save a load of space and use them?
>
> 2:How about instead of using one dialect (and alienate many a
> potential editor), have the dialects used within the articles be
> identified somewhere at the beginning of the page?
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, amd64_hacker <amd64_hacker@...>
> wrote:
> >
> > Ah, a topic I'm very interested in - transliteration. :)
> >
> > Anyone can download the database and set up their own "wikipedia" if
> > they want.
> > So you don't actually need the permission of the wikipedia guys to set
> > up Quikipedia.
> > Of course you won't have a dot wikipedia dot org domain name, but it's
> > totally feasible.
> >
> > IMHO:
> >
> > 1) It should be typed and stored as junior quikscript.
> > Senior is just junior with font shaping, a rendering issue, since we're
> > in a wikipedia mood:
> > See also: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_text_layout
> <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_text_layout>
> >
> > 2) Easy, just use the _correct_ British pronunciation.
> > Just kidding (mostly) please don't flame me. :-)
> > You'd either have to go with one pronunciation or you'd need to have a
> > separate wikipedia for each.
> >
> > 3) Which issues?
> > If we're talking about sorting then I'd go for:
> > 1-40 followed by Loch, Llan, Examine and Excite since that's the order
> > they're introduced to us in The Quikscript Alphabet.
> >
> > steveb_667 wrote:
> > >
> > > I have an idea & I would like some feedback on it.
> > >
> > > In short, I was wondering about the feasibility of having a Wikipedia
> > > written entirely in Quikscript.
> > >
> > > I'm not sure if anyone has ever proposed a similar idea to Wikipedia
> > > in the past. For the most part, Wikipedia has occasionally delved into
> > > giving artificial languages their own wiki. I have yet to know of
> > > Wikipedia giving a wiki to a phonetic alphabet.
> > >
> > > It is in my view that a Quikipedia would be a great asset to the
> > > existing Quikscript community. It would encourage enrollment growth,
> > > increase the alphabet's visibility to a larger community of people &
> > > help existing members practice with their typing skills in a rewarding
> > > manner.
> > >
> > > Hurdles, naturally, need to be overcome for this Quikipedia to become
> > > reality. These concerns include, but may not be limited to, the
> following:
> > >
> > > 1). What form of Quikscript to use? Junior? Senior? A mix?
> > >
> > > 2). How are we to resolve legitimate phonetic differences with the
> > > same word from different countries?
> > >
> > > 3). What system should we set up to resolve emergent issues with the
> > > alphabet?
> > >
> > > At any rate, have fun with the idea.
> > >
> > >
> >
>
>
